thread.title: Yankees clinch playoff spot after 2-year absence, top Boston
thread.title_full: Yankees clinch playoff spot after 2-year absence, top Boston

title: Yankees clinch playoff spot after 2-year absence, top Boston
text:
Updated: 10:29 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015 | Posted: 10:29 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015 Yankees clinch playoff spot after 2-year absence, top Boston Related View Larger New York Yankees Carlos Beltran, right, points skyward as he crosses the plate after hitting a second-inning, solo, home run off Boston Red Sox starting pitcher Rich Hill in a baseball game in New York, Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. Red Sox catcher Sandy Leon is at left. (AP Photo/Kathy Willens) View Larger New York Yankees on-deck batter John Ryan Murphy greets Yankees Carlos Beltran after Beltran hit a second-inning, solo home run off Boston Red Sox starting pitcher Rich Hill in a baseball game in New York, Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. (AP Photo/Kathy Willens) View Larger New York Yankees Carlos Beltran, left, trots the bases as Boston Red Sox starting pitcher Rich Hill looks to the outfield after allowing a second-inning, solo, home run to Beltran in a baseball game in New York, Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. (AP Photo/Kathy Willens) By RONALD BLUM The Associated Press NEW YORK â€” 
The New York Yankees clinched an AL wild-card spot Thursday night, ending a two-year absence from the postseason by beating the Boston Red Sox 4-1. 
Carlos Beltran and rookies Greg Bird and Rob Refsnyder all homered for the Yankees in the franchise's 10,000th regular-season win. 
CC Sabathia (6-10) won for the second time since the All-Star break. 
Putting behind the venerated generation of Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera, the Yankees open the playoffs with a winner-take-all game on Tuesday, most likely against Houston or the Los Angeles Angels. 
New York had failed to reach the playoffs in consecutive years for the first time since its 1982-93 drought, just before the start of a golden age that included five World Series titles and seven AL pennants from 1996-2009. Copyright The Associated Press
